chunks.original_text: 祥光照室，众恶不侵。 八十一年不觉其久。 至商二十一王武丁之九年庚辰岁二月建寅十五日卯时，圣母因攀李枝，忽从左腋降生仙传所载，皆云在胎八十一年。 唯内传云：上帝之师元君，感日精入口，因娠。 经七十二年，剖左腋而生。 二说虽或不同，然亦有由。 虞宣出塞记云：老子复命胞中七十二年，举候九年。 则亦入十一年也。 是时阳景重耀，祥云荫庭，万鹤翔空，九天称庆。 玉女跪捧，九龙荐水，以浴圣姿。 龙出之地，因成九井汉伏滔《北征记》云：老君庙中有九井，水皆相通，故每汲一井，九井皆动。 降生之初，即行九步，步生莲华。 左手指天，右手指地，曰：天上地下，惟道独尊，我当开扬无上道法，普度一切动植众生，周褊十方及幽牢地狱应度未度，咸悉度之。 隐显人问，为国师范。 位登太极无上神仙，号曰：聘或作檐者，汉字通用也，名耳，字伯阳，或曰：伯阳父者，尊老之称也。 一名雅，字伯宗。 一名志，字伯光。 一名石，字孟公。 一名重，字子文。 一名定，字元阳。 一名元，字伯始。 一名显，字元生。 一名德，字伯文，老君降生九日，身有九变，皆天冠天衣，自然被体。 仍有七十二相，八十一好。 七十二相者，头圆如天，面光象日伏晨起。 玉枕穹隆，皓发如鹤，长七尺余。 眉如北斗，其色翠绿。 虎髭龙髯，素结如丝。 耳有垂珠，中有三门，高平於顶，厚而且坚。 河目日光，方瞳绿筋，鼻有双柱，准骨隆隆。 口方如海，唇赤如丹。 气有紫色，其香若兰。 齿如编贝，其坚若银。 数有六八，上下均平。 舌长且广，形如锦纹。 其音如玉，其响如金。 观高而起，颐方若矩。 日角月渊，金容玉姿。 龙颜肃肃，凤视闲闲。 额有兑象，三午上达。 天庭平坦，金匮充盈。 颊有白痣，颐有玉丸。 项有三约，鹤素昂昂。 垂臂过膝，手握十纹。 其指纤长，各有策文。 爪有玉甲，身有绿毛。 胸有偃骨，背有河魁。 脐深逾寸，腹软如绵。 心有锦纹，腹有玄志。 眼有轮文，足蹈二骗。 指有乾坤，身长丈二。 遍体芳香，面方而泽。 上下三停，体如金刚。 貌若琉璃，行如虎步，动若龙趋。 此其相也。 左扶青龙，右据白虎，前导朱雀，后从玄武。 头荫紫云，足履莲花，项负双景，五明耀日。 身有圆象，洞照九天。 兼前仙相，光色奇妍。 总八十一，谓之好也。 寄胎八十一年，极太阳九九之数。 生而皓首，故号为老。 古人称师为子，又子者男子之通称，故号老子。 居於陈国苦县濑乡曲仁里涡水之阴即今亳州卫真县也。 圣母既诞育道身，将返天阙。 复元君之位，欲示世人以师资传授之道，乃告老君曰：夫人受生於天地，中有清有浊。 气之清者清明慈仁，气之浊者愚痴凶虐。 明者因修以成性，昧者恣欲以伤命。 性者身之原也，命者生之根也。 是故修学之人，炼身於九丹，解结於五神，引气於本生，灭根於三关。 九炼十变，百节开明。 胞结断灭，乃知本真而成上仙也。 若不修学，则邪魔入身，百病竞生，死不尽命，痛乎难言。 夫仙由心学，心诚则仙成，道贵内求内密，则道来能致静以合真，积虚以通神，则取仙日近矣。 苟心竞神劳，体烦不专，动静丧精，耳目广明，徒积稔索道，道愈远也。 寄寓天地问，少许时尔。
chunks.translated_text:
The auspicious radiance illuminated her chamber, and no evil could assail her. Eighty-one years passed unnoticed. In the ninth year of King Wuding of the twenty-first Shang dynasty, the *gengchen* year, on the fifteenth day of the second month (the *jianyin* month) at the hour of *mao*, the sagely mother, grasping a plum branch, suddenly gave birth from beneath her left armpit. As recorded in the *Immortals’ Biographies*, all accounts state he remained in the womb for eighty-one years. Only the *Inner Transmission* states: The Supreme Master of the Celestial Court, moved by the essence of the sun entering her mouth, conceived. After seventy-two years, he emerged by cleaving her left armpit. Though the two accounts differ, there is reason for both. The *Yu Xuan’s Records of the Northern Frontier* states: Laozi remained in the womb for seventy-two years, with nine years of gestation thereafter—totaling eighty-one years.

At that moment, the sun’s brilliance doubled, auspicious clouds shaded the courtyard, ten thousand cranes soared in the sky, and the Nine Heavens resounded with celebration. Jade maidens knelt to cradle him, and nine dragons offered water to bathe his sacred form. Where the dragons emerged, nine wells formed. As recorded in Fu Tao’s *Records of the Northern Expedition*: Within Laozi’s temple stand nine wells, their waters all connected—drawing from one causes all nine to stir.

At his birth, he took nine steps, each step birthing a lotus. His left hand pointed to heaven, his right hand to earth, and he declared: “Between heaven and earth, only the Dao is supreme. I shall propagate the supreme Daoist teachings, universally delivering all sentient beings—whether moving or rooted—throughout the ten directions and the dark prisons of hell, redeeming all who await deliverance. Manifest or hidden, among humankind, I shall serve as the nation’s teacher and model.” Thus, he ascended to the rank of Supreme Immortal of the Great Ultimate, bearing the title *Pin* (or *Yan*—interchangeable in Han script), his given name *Er*, courtesy name *Boyang*. Some call him *Boyang Fu*, a term of reverence for the aged. Alternate names include: *Ya*, courtesy name *Bozong*; *Zhi*, courtesy name *Boguang*; *Shi*, courtesy name *Menggong*; *Chong*, courtesy name *Ziwen*; *Ding*, courtesy name *Yuanyang*; *Yuan*, courtesy name *Boshi*; *Xian*, courtesy name *Yuansheng*; *De*, courtesy name *Bowen*.

Nine days after his birth, his body underwent nine transformations, each time clad in celestial robes and a celestial crown, naturally adorned. He possessed seventy-two marks and eighty-one excellences. The seventy-two marks were as follows: his head round as heaven, his face radiant as the sun and moon; his jade-like occiput arched, his hair white as a crane’s, over seven *chi* in length. His brows resembled the Northern Dipper, their color emerald green. His beard was tiger-like, his whiskers dragon-like, white and silken. His ears bore hanging pearls, with three passages within, rising level with his crown, thick and firm. His eyes were like rivers, his pupils square with green veins; his nose had twin pillars, its bridge high and prominent. His mouth was square as the sea, his lips red as cinnabar. His breath carried a purple hue, its fragrance like orchids. His teeth were like strung cowries, strong as silver, thirty-two in number, evenly aligned. His tongue was long and broad, patterned like brocade. His voice was like jade, its resonance like metal. His forehead was high and broad, his jaw square as a carpenter’s square. His temples bore the sun’s angle and the moon’s depth, his visage golden, his bearing jade-like. His dragon-like countenance was solemn, his phoenix-like gaze serene. His forehead bore the trigram *dui*, the three *wu* lines ascending. His celestial court was level and expansive, his golden coffer full. His cheeks bore white moles, his jaw a jade pellet. His neck had three folds, white and crane-like. His arms hung past his knees, his hands bore ten whorls. His fingers were slender and long, each marked with auspicious lines. His nails were like jade, his body covered in green down. His chest bore the *yan* bone, his back the *he kui*. His navel was over an inch deep, his belly soft as silk. His heart bore brocade-like patterns, his abdomen a dark intent. His eyes had wheel-like veins, his feet trod the two *pian* stars. His toes bore the symbols of *qian* and *kun*, his height twelve *chi*. His entire body exuded fragrance, his face square and lustrous. His form was proportioned in three equal parts, his body like vajra. His appearance was as luminous as lapis lazuli, his gait like a tiger’s, his movements like a dragon’s. Such were his marks.

To his left stood the Azure Dragon, to his right the White Tiger; before him the Vermilion Bird led, behind him the Dark Warrior followed. Purple clouds shaded his head, lotuses bore his feet, twin luminaries crowned his neck, and fivefold brilliance shone like the sun. His body bore the round symbol, illuminating the Nine Heavens. Combined with his previous immortal marks, their radiance was wondrously fair—eighty-one in total, called his excellences.

His gestation of eighty-one years fulfilled the supreme yang number of nine nines. Born with white hair, he was thus called *Lao* (Old). The ancients addressed teachers as *zi* (Master), and *zi* was also a general term for men, hence the name *Laozi*. He dwelled in Li Xiang of Qu Ren Village, Ku County, Chen State, on the northern bank of the Wo River—present-day Weizhen County in Bozhou.

After giving birth to the Dao-incarnate body, the sagely mother returned to the celestial palace, resuming her position as the Primordial Lord. To demonstrate to the world the way of master-disciple transmission, she addressed Laozi: “All beings born between heaven and earth possess both purity and turbidity. Those of pure *qi* are clear-minded, compassionate, and kind; those of turbid *qi* are foolish, cruel, and violent. The enlightened cultivate to refine their nature; the deluded indulge desires to harm their lives. Nature is the source of the body; life is the root of existence. Thus, those who cultivate and study refine their bodies with the nine elixirs, untie the knots of the five spirits, guide *qi* to its origin, and sever the roots at the three barriers. Through nine refinements and ten transformations, the hundred joints become luminous. When the fetal knots are severed, one knows the original truth and ascends as a supreme immortal. Without cultivation, demonic influences enter the body, a hundred illnesses arise, life is not fully lived, and suffering is beyond words.

Immortality arises from the heart’s study. With sincerity, immortality is achieved. The Dao values inner seeking; inner secrecy brings the Dao. Cultivate stillness to unite with the true, accumulate emptiness to commune with the divine, and the day of attaining immortality draws near. If the heart competes and the spirit labors, the body grows restless and unfocused, movement and stillness dissipate essence, the ears and eyes grow overly keen—even with long accumulation, the Dao remains distant. This sojourn in the world of heaven and earth is but a fleeting moment.”
chunks.overlap_context: sun. After a long while, the sun gradually shrank and fell from the heavens as a five-colored pearl, the size of a pellet. She cupped it in her hands and swallowed it, awakening to find herself with child. Today, at the Celestial Tranquility Palace in Bozhou, the Flowing Star Altar marks the site. Thereafter, her complexion grew ever more youthful, and her spirit remained serene. In the chamber where she dwelt, the six qi harmonized—winter brought no biting cold, nor summer any oppressive heat.

chunks.original_text: 若能摄气营神，辛苦注真，久将得道，则与天地共寄寓太无中也。 能洞虚体无，则视之不见，听之不闻，乃与道合真矣。 老子曰：今混迩尘寰，欲常存不死，随世度人，可乎？ 元君曰：吾有秘宝，非圣不传。 有能修之，可以长存。 老子曰：愿闻其致。 元君曰：至道渊奥，探不可识。 匪有匪无，匪声匪色。 视之不见，搏之不得。 囊括天地，至大无极。 近在诸身，莫之能测。 能知其则，是谓玄德。 老子曰：其道亦有术以致之乎？ 元君曰：道者虚通之至真，术者变化之玄技。 道因术以济人，人因修而会道，则变化无穷矣。 夫道之要者，无为而自然； 术之秘者，符与气药而已。 符者三光之灵文，天之真性也。 药者五行之华英，地之精液也。 气者阴阳之和粹，万物之灵爽也。 人虽得一事未毕，要资符药道乃讫。 此吾之秘宝尔。 能兼之，可以长存。 度人无量矣。 老君曰：身者得道之器也。 气者致命之根也。 根拔则命终，器败则道去。 今欲修之，令命固道隆，可得闻乎？ 元君曰：人禀骨肉之资，犹陶家逐也。 逐未冶则败速，身未炼则命促，理固然也。 纵使德冠群有，神疏太玄，而身犹未免乎老死。 夫何故哉？ 由化致然，不得不然也。 惟药能炼形，符能致神。 神归则心通而性逸，形坚则气固而命全。 然后化气变精，洞入无形，飞行虚空，存亡自然，乃能长存。 得道之人，虽遭劫交，天地崩沦，而灾不能及。 所以贵乎符药者，由此也。 老君曰：服神丹而长生者，神灵佑之乎，将药之力邪？ 元君曰：长生之功．由於丹，丹之成由於神。 故将合丹，必正身心，不履罪过，神明佑之，作丹必成。 神丹入口，寿无穷已。 天地明察，道归仁人。 万兆蠢蠢，名日行尸，不信长生之可学，谓为虚诞。 从朝至暮，但作求死之事，天岂能强生乎？ 恣心尽欲，奄忽辄死，千金送葬，何所益哉？ 则神丹之道成，不惟长生，而亦可作世宝也。 知此道者，亦安用天下为。 人有以国易吾方，而非其人不传也。 老子稽首曰：愿闻其旨。 元君乃仰天而啸，倏忽有紫云如盖，自天奄至。 中有五色，蕴光明八达。 仙人涓子侍之，元君披出神图宝章变化之方、还丹伏火水汞液金之术，凡七十二篇，以授老君。 其文日．．一为玄白生金公，太阳流珠入华池。 斤内五两文萎袭，赤盐白雪成雄雌。 五符九丹得之飞，真道在此人不知。 五符者，一日玄白，二日金精，三日飞符，四日金华，五日三五青龙精。 九丹者，一日白雪九转还丹，二日雌雄九转还丹，三曰黄华九转还丹，四日白华九转还丹，· 五日丹华九转还丹，六日五色九转还丹，七日泥汞九转还丹，八曰金精九转还丹，九日九鼎极耀还丹。 此九丹，得一则可以长生，不在褊作也。 神丹之道，皆三化五转，至九而止。 得服之者，与吾等矣。 神仙之道，不在祭祀祷鬼神，不在导引与屈伸，不在叹愿多语言，不在精思自苦勤。 长生之要在神丹，知之甚易为实难，子能行之可长存。 此之道存立得仙，吾亦学得非自然。 老子再叩头稽首曰：九丹之道既奉慈训矣，窃闻求仙不得金液，虚自苦辛，愿示其要。 元君曰：大哉子之问也。 九丹金液，同为升天之道。 然九丹中金液为上。 所以尔者，服九丹之人，或三年，或二年，或一年或半年，或百日六十日、三十日、三日，乃有仙官云龙来迎。

If one can gather qi to nourish the spirit, endure hardship to concentrate on the true, and persist long enough, one will attain the Dao and dwell with heaven and earth in the Great Void. When one can penetrate emptiness and embody nothingness, sight cannot perceive, hearing cannot detect—then one merges with the Dao in truth.

Laozi said: "Now, amidst the dust and chaos of the world, can one hope to preserve life eternally and guide others across the ages?"
The Primordial Lord replied: "I possess a secret treasure, transmitted only to the sagely. Those who cultivate it may endure forever."
Laozi said: "I wish to hear of its attainment."
The Primordial Lord said: "The supreme Dao is profound and obscure, beyond all knowing. Neither being nor non-being, neither sound nor form. Invisible when sought, intangible when grasped. It encompasses heaven and earth, boundless and infinite. Yet it lies near within each body, unfathomable to all. To know its principle is called mysterious virtue."

Laozi said: "Does the Dao also have methods to attain it?"
The Primordial Lord said: "The Dao is the ultimate truth of emptiness and penetration; methods are the wondrous arts of transformation. The Dao employs methods to aid humanity, and through cultivation, one meets the Dao—then transformations become limitless. The essence of the Dao lies in non-action and spontaneity; the secrecy of methods lies in talismans, qi, and elixirs alone. Talismans are the numinous script of the Three Luminaries, the true nature of heaven. Elixirs are the essence and bloom of the Five Phases, the vital fluid of earth. Qi is the harmonious purity of yin and yang, the spirit and brightness of all things. Though one may master a single practice, one must still rely on talismans, elixirs, and the Dao to complete it. This is my secret treasure. To master them together is to endure forever and deliver countless beings."

Laozi said: "The body is the vessel for attaining the Dao; qi is the root of life. When the root is severed, life ends; when the vessel decays, the Dao departs. Now, if one wishes to cultivate it so that life is secure and the Dao flourishes, may I hear how?"
The Primordial Lord said: "Humans are endowed with bones and flesh, like clay in a potter’s hands. If the clay is left unworked, it quickly spoils; if the body is left unrefined, life is short—such is the principle. Even if one’s virtue surpasses all others and the spirit communes with the Great Mystery, the body still cannot escape aging and death. Why is this? It is the nature of transformation, inevitable and unyielding. Only elixirs can refine the form, and only talismans can summon the spirit. When the spirit returns, the heart opens and the nature is at ease; when the form is firm, qi is secure and life is preserved. Then, transforming qi into essence, one penetrates formlessness, soars through the void, and masters life and death—thus enduring forever. Those who attain the Dao, though they face the turning of kalpas and the collapse of heaven and earth, remain untouched by disaster. This is why talismans and elixirs are so precious."

Laozi said: "Those who ingest the divine elixir and live forever—is it the protection of spirits, or the power of the elixir?"
The Primordial Lord said: "The merit of long life lies in the elixir; the elixir’s completion lies in the spirit. Thus, when compounding the elixir, one must rectify body and mind, avoid transgressions, and the spirit will protect it—then the elixir will surely form. When the divine elixir enters the mouth, life knows no end. Heaven and earth bear witness: the Dao returns to the benevolent. The teeming masses, like walking corpses, do not believe long life can be learned, dismissing it as empty fantasy. From dawn to dusk, they engage only in acts that hasten death—how can heaven force them to live? Indulging desires to the full, they perish in an instant, and though a thousand gold pieces are spent on their burial, what benefit is there? When the Way of the divine elixir is perfected, not only does one attain long life, but it may also become a treasure of the world. Those who know this Way—what need have they for the world? If one offered a kingdom in exchange for my formula, I would not transmit it to the unworthy."

Laozi bowed deeply and said: "I wish to hear its essentials."
The Primordial Lord then raised his head and let out a long whistle. Suddenly, a purple cloud like a canopy descended from the heavens, suffused with five colors and radiant light spreading in all directions. The immortal Juanzi attended him, and the Primordial Lord unfurled the sacred charts of divine transformations, the methods of returning elixirs, refining cinnabar, subduing fire, and the arts of liquid mercury and gold—seventy-two scrolls in all—and bestowed them upon Laozi. Their texts read:

*First, the Mysterious White gives birth to the Golden Elder,
The sun’s flowing pearl enters the Flowery Pond.
Within the pound, five taels of patterned cinnabar gather,
Red salt and white snow form the male and female.
With the Five Talismans and Nine Elixirs, one may ascend—
The true Way lies here, yet none know it.*

The Five Talismans are: first, the Mysterious White; second, the Golden Essence; third, the Flying Talisman; fourth, the Golden Bloom; fifth, the Three-Five Azure Dragon Essence.
The Nine Elixirs are: first, the White Snow Nine-Turn Returning Elixir; second, the Male-Female Nine-Turn Returning Elixir; third, the Yellow Bloom Nine-Turn Returning Elixir; fourth, the White Bloom Nine-Turn Returning Elixir; fifth, the Elixir Bloom Nine-Turn Returning Elixir; sixth, the Five-Color Nine-Turn Returning Elixir; seventh, the Clay Mercury Nine-Turn Returning Elixir; eighth, the Golden Essence Nine-Turn Returning Elixir; ninth, the Nine Cauldrons’ Radiant Ultimate Elixir. Of these nine elixirs, obtaining even one allows one to live forever—there is no need to practice them all.

The Way of the divine elixir undergoes three transformations and five turns, culminating in nine. Those who ingest it become equal to me. The Way of immortals does not lie in sacrifices or prayers to spirits, nor in guiding and stretching exercises, nor in sighing wishes or verbose speech, nor in exhausting oneself with intense thought. The essence of long life lies in the divine elixir—knowing it is easy, but practicing it is truly difficult. If you can follow it, you may endure forever. This Way exists to attain immortality; even I learned it—it is not innate."

Laozi bowed again and said: "I have received your gracious instruction on the Nine Elixirs. Yet I have heard that without the Golden Liquid, one’s efforts to seek immortality are in vain. I humbly wish to know its essentials."
The Primordial Lord said: "Your question is profound indeed. The Nine Elixirs and the Golden Liquid are both paths to ascending to heaven. Yet among the Nine Elixirs, the Golden Liquid is supreme. Those who ingest the Nine Elixirs may, after three years, two years, one year, half a year, a hundred days, sixty days, thirty days, or even three days, be welcomed by immortal officials with clouds and dragons."

chunks.original_text: 惟服金液者，入口则身色紫金，立生羽翼，升天为仙官矣。 凡欲服之，须先长斋，断谷一年，乃得服之。 自非有玄中之录及不死之名者，终不得闻金液之道也。 其法依前合丹，金成而液之，其道毕矣。 此吾之秘宝也。 凡有千二百诀，吾於往劫尘沙天地之先受之於元始天尊，奉而行之，得居无上元君之位。 吾昔已传至真大圣天帝、上· 帝、太微太一元君，今又授尔，尔其勉之。 老君受讫，复请曰：万兆芸芸，动之死地，今以此广济，如何？ 元君曰：悠悠之徒，耽荣嗜欲死者，若坠石投川，往而不返，甚可痛伤。 然道不虚行，必授其人。 此道高妙，秘於九玄琼台云岌，万年一行，贻诸玄录玉名耳。 自非宿命骨分及丹苦之人，不得闻也。 愚人多过，方向驱除，乌得违天科而妄宣乎？ 吾道尽此，将去矣，当遣太一元君语汝。 言讫，即有千乘万骑、五帝上真拥八景玉舆迎之升天今太清神丹经，其法乃出於无上元君。 其神能调和阴阳，役使风雨，进退五星，斟酌寒暑。 縿驾九龙十二白虎，天下众仙皆仰隶焉。 人之生死，莫不由此，犹言服丹所致也。 太一元君 老君乃远游山泽，求炼神丹。 行经劳山，果遇太一元君，乘五色斑麟，侍官数十人。 老君从之问道，元君曰：道之要，在乎还丹金液耳。 遂具授秘诀。 他年之历山，复会太一元君。 因谢神丹之方。 元君曰：吾是群仙之尊，万道之主，玄灵秘术，本玄分也，奚辱谢焉。 老君曰：凡民无知，死者甚众，抚心泣血，见之伤悲。 欲给以神药，令皆得长生，可乎？ 元君曰：不可。 生道至重，必授大贤及孝顺笃实之士。 天生万物，有善有恶，善者宜生，恶者宜除。 不足给药令皆生也。 君已知之，不可轻泄。 老君以神仙之道必假修炼，欲垂法以劝来世，故存真抱一，炼丹服气，然后乘空凌虚，出有入无，随意所适，人莫能测。 一日乘白鹿复履庭桧而升天。 金母元君 金母元君者，九灵太妙龟山金母也。 一号太灵九光龟台金母，一号日西王母，乃西华之至妙洞阴之极尊。 在昔道气凝寂，湛体无为，将欲启迪玄功，生化万物，先以束华至真之气化而生木公焉。 木公生於碧海之上，苍灵之墟，以生阳和之气，理於束方，亦号日王公焉。 又以西华至妙之气化而生金母焉。 金母生於神洲伊川，厥姓猴氏，生而飞翔，以主阴灵之气，理於西方，亦号王母。 皆挺质大元，毓神玄奥。 於西方渺莽之中，分大道醇精之气，结气成形。 与束王木公，共理二气，而育养天地，陶钧万物矣。 体柔顺之本，为极阴之元，位配西方，母养群品。 天上天下，三界十方，女子之登仙得道者，咸所隶焉。 所居宫阙，在龟山之舂山，昆仑玄圃闱风之苑，有金城千重，玉楼十二，琼华之阙，光碧之堂，九层玄台，紫翠丹房。 左带瑶池，右环翠水。 其山之下，弱水九重，洪涛万丈，非讽车羽输不可到也尚书帝验期贝．王母之国在西荒之野。 所谓玉阙坚天，绿台承霄，青琳之字，朱紫之房，连琳彩帐，明月四朗。 戴华胜，佩灵章。 左侍仙女，右侍羽童。 宝盖杳映，羽饰荫庭。 轩砌之下，殖以白环之树，丹刚之林。 空青万条，瑶干千寻。 无风而神籁自出，琅然皆奏八会之音也。 神洲在昆仑之束南，故《尔雅》云：西王母日下是矣。
chunks.translated_text:
Only those who ingest the Golden Liquid will, upon taking it into their mouths, find their bodies suffused with a hue of purple-gold, wings sprouting forthwith, ascending to heaven to become immortal officials. Those who wish to ingest it must first observe a prolonged fast, abstain from grains for a full year, and only then may they partake of it. Unless one’s name is recorded in the Register of the Mysterious Center and bears the title of the Undying, one shall never hear of the Way of the Golden Liquid. Its method follows the previous alchemy of compounding the elixir; once the gold is formed, it is liquified, and the Way is complete. This is my secret treasure. It comprises one thousand two hundred incantations, which I received from the Primordial Celestial Worthy in the distant kalpas before the dust of countless worlds arose. I practiced them faithfully and thus attained the rank of Supreme Primordial Lord. In former times, I transmitted them to the Perfected, the Great Sage, the Celestial Emperor, the Supreme Emperor, and the Primordial Lord of the Grand Tenuity and Grand Unity. Now I bestow them upon you—strive diligently in their cultivation."

Laozi, having received the transmission, again inquired: "The teeming multitudes of the world, driven to the brink of death—if this Way were widely bestowed to deliver them, how might it be done?"

The Primordial Lord replied: "The careless masses, lost in indulgence and desire, perish like stones cast into rivers, gone without return—how grievous and lamentable! Yet the Dao does not act in vain; it must be entrusted to the worthy. This Way is lofty and wondrous, concealed within the Nine Mysteries’ Jasper Terrace and Cloudy Peaks. Once in ten thousand years, it is transmitted only to those whose names are inscribed in the Mysterious Register. Unless one is destined by innate bone and has endured the trials of alchemical refinement, one shall not hear of it. Fools err repeatedly, only then seeking to purge their faults—how could one defy celestial decree and recklessly divulge it? My teachings end here. I shall depart now, but the Primordial Lord of the Grand Unity will speak with you further."

As he finished speaking, a thousand chariots and ten thousand riders, the Perfected of the Five Emperors, escorted him in an eight-scene jade carriage, ascending to heaven.

The *Divine Elixir Scripture of the Grand Clarity* records that its method originates from the Supreme Primordial Lord. Its divine power harmonizes yin and yang, commands wind and rain, advances and retreats the five stars, and regulates cold and heat. It harnesses nine dragons and twelve white tigers, and all immortals under heaven revere and submit to it. The life and death of humankind are governed by this—indeed, it is said to arise from the ingestion of the elixir.

The Primordial Lord of the Grand Unity
Laozi then wandered through mountains and marshes, seeking to refine the divine elixir. Passing through Mount Lao, he encountered the Primordial Lord of the Grand Unity, riding a five-colored mottled qilin, attended by dozens of officials. Laozi followed and inquired of the Way. The Primordial Lord said: "The essence of the Dao lies in the returning elixir and the Golden Liquid." Thereupon, he fully transmitted the secret incantations. In later years, on Mount Li, Laozi again met the Primordial Lord of the Grand Unity and expressed gratitude for the divine elixir’s method. The Primordial Lord replied: "I am the sovereign of all immortals, the master of the myriad Ways. The mysterious and numinous arts are rooted in the profound—why should you demean yourself with thanks?"

Laozi said: "The common people, ignorant and dying in great numbers, move me to tears of blood. I grieve to see it. If I could bestow upon them the divine medicine, allowing all to attain longevity, would it be permissible?"

The Primordial Lord replied: "It may not be done. The Way of life is most weighty; it must be entrusted only to the greatly virtuous, the filial, the sincere, and the steadfast. Heaven generates the myriad things—some good, some evil. The good are fit to live; the evil are fit to be eradicated. It is not fitting to dispense the medicine to all, allowing them to live. You already understand this—do not lightly disclose it."

Laozi, recognizing that the Way of immortality requires cultivation, wished to leave behind a method to encourage future generations. Thus, he preserved authenticity, embraced the One, refined the elixir, and ingested qi. Thereafter, he soared through the void, transcending existence and non-existence, traveling wherever he willed, beyond mortal comprehension. One day, he mounted a white deer, trod upon the cypress of the courtyard, and ascended to heaven.

The Primordial Lady of Metal
The Primordial Lady of Metal is the Nine Numinous, Most Wondrous, Tortoise Mountain Primordial Lady of Metal. She is also called the Most Numinous Nine Radiance, Tortoise Terrace Primordial Lady of Metal, and the Queen Mother of the West. She is the supreme mystery of the Western Florescence, the ultimate honor of the Dark Yin. In ancient times, when the qi of the Dao congealed in stillness, her essence abided in non-action. Desiring to initiate the profound work of generating and transforming the myriad things, she first transformed the Perfect Qi of the Eastern Florescence, giving birth to Lord Wood. Lord Wood was born upon the Azure Sea, in the Wilderness of the Blue Numinous, to govern the qi of harmonious yang in the East—he is also called the Lord King of the East. Then, from the Perfect Qi of the Western Florescence, she transformed and gave birth to the Primordial Lady of Metal. The Primordial Lady of Metal was born in the Divine Continent’s Yi River, her surname being Hou. Born with the ability to soar, she governs the qi of numinous yin in the West—she is also called the Queen Mother. Both emerged with great primordial substance, nurturing the mysterious and profound. In the vast wilderness of the West, they divided the pure essence of the Great Dao, condensing qi into form. Together with Lord Wood of the East, they govern the two qi, nurturing heaven and earth, shaping the myriad things.

Their essence embodies the root of gentleness and compliance, the origin of ultimate yin. Their position corresponds to the West, where they mother and nourish all beings. In heaven above and below, across the Three Realms and Ten Directions, all women who ascend as immortals and attain the Dao are subject to her. Her palaces and towers reside on Tortoise Mountain’s Chong Mountain, in the Garden of the Kunlun’s Mysterious Orchard and the Gate of the Wind. There are a thousand layers of golden walls, twelve jade towers, jasper palaces, halls of luminous azure, nine-tiered mysterious terraces, and vermilion chambers of purple and emerald. To the left flows the Jasper Pool; to the right winds the Emerald River. At the mountain’s base lie nine layers of weak water, with waves ten thousand fathoms high—none may reach it without a wind-driven carriage or feathered conveyance.

The *Book of Documents* and the *Divine Verifications of the Emperors* state: The Queen Mother’s realm lies in the wilds of the Western Wastes. There stand jade towers firm as heaven, green terraces supporting the clouds, chambers of azure jade, and halls of vermilion and purple. Linked jade canopies and luminous curtains glow with the brightness of four moons. She wears floral crowns and bears numinous insignia. To her left attend immortal maidens; to her right, feathered youths. Her jeweled canopy casts a distant glow; feathered ornaments shade the courtyard. Beneath the balustrades grow trees of white jade and forests of cinnabar-hardness. Ten thousand branches of malachite, a thousand trunks of jasper—though no wind blows, divine music arises of its own, resonating with the eight harmonies.

The Divine Continent lies southeast of Kunlun, hence the *Erya* states: "The Queen Mother of the West is beneath the sun."

chunks.original_text: 又云：王母髦发戴胜，虎齿善啸者，此乃王母之使，金方白虎之神，非王母之真形也。 元始天王授以万天之统，龟山九光之录，使制召万灵，统括真圣，监盟证信，总诸天之羽仪。 天尊上圣朝宴之会，考校之所，王母皆临映焉。 上清宝经三洞玉书，凡所授度，咸所关与也。 昔黄帝讨蚩尤之暴，威所未禁，而蚩尤幻化多方，征风召雨，吹姻喷雾，师众大迷。 帝归息太山之阿，昏然忧寐。 王母遣使披玄狐之裘，以符授帝曰：太一在前，得之者胜，战则克矣。 符广三寸，长一尺，青莹如玉，丹血为文。 佩符既毕，王母乃命一妇人，人首乌身，谓帝曰：我九天玄女也。 授帝以三官五意阴阳之略，太一遁甲六壬步斗之术，阴符之机，灵宝五符五胜之文。 遂克蚩尤於中冀剪。 神农之后，诛榆冈於版泉而天下大定，都於上谷之涿鹿。 又数年，王母遣使白虎之神，乘白虎集帝之庭，授以地图，晚年复授帝以清静无为正真之减，其辞曰：饮啄不止身不轻，思虑不止神不清，声色不止心不宁。 心不宁则神不灵，神不灵则道不成。 其要妙也，不在瞻星礼斗，苦己劳形。 贵在湛然方寸，无所营营。 神仙之道，乃可长生。 其后虞舜摄位，王母遣使授舜白玉环，又授益地图，遂广黄帝之九州为十有二州。 王母又遣使授舜皇管，吹之以和八风。 周昭王二十五年岁在乙卯，老君与真人尹喜游观八弦之外，西游龟台，为西王母说常清摩经，故太极左官仙公葛玄序曰：吾昔受之於东华帝君，东华帝君受之於金阙帝君，金阙帝君受之於西王母，皆口口相传，不记文字，吾今於世书而录之，逮至穆王命驾八骏之乘，右服辟骊而左绿耳，右縿赤骥而左白药。 主车则造父为御，高局为右。 次车之乘，右服渠黄而左逾轮，左縿盗骊而右字，柏夭主车，参百为御，奔戎为右，驰驱千里而至巨搜氏之国。

It is further said: "The Queen Mother with flowing hair and a sheng-crown, tiger-teeth and a piercing cry—this is but her messenger, the White Tiger Spirit of the Metal Realm, not her true form." The Primordial Heavenly King bestowed upon her the governance of the myriad heavens, the *Nine Radiance Register of Mount Gui*, commanding her to summon all spirits, unify the perfected sages, oversee oaths and bear witness, and preside over the feathered regalia of all heavens. At the assemblies where the Heavenly Worthy and Supreme Saints gather for feasting and judgment, the Queen Mother ever attends in radiant presence.

The precious scriptures of the *Shangqing*, the Three Caverns, and the jade texts—all that she transmits and ordains—are matters in which she holds sway. In ancient times, when the Yellow Emperor campaigned against the tyranny of Chiyou, his might could not prevail, for Chiyou wrought manifold illusions, summoning winds and calling rains, exhaling mists and spewing fog, so that the imperial host fell into utter confusion. The Emperor withdrew to rest at the foot of Mount Tai, sunk in troubled slumber. The Queen Mother dispatched a messenger clad in a robe of dark fox-fur, who presented him with a talisman, saying: "With the Great Unity before you, he who obtains it shall triumph; in battle, he shall conquer." The talisman measured three inches in breadth and one foot in length, lustrous as jade, its script traced in cinnabar. Once the Emperor had fastened it to his person, the Queen Mother sent forth a woman with a human head and the body of a crow, who addressed him: "I am the Dark Woman of the Nine Heavens." She imparted to him the esoteric arts of the Three Offices and Five Intentions, the mysteries of yin and yang, the techniques of the Great Unity, the *Dun Jia*, the *Liu Ren*, the pacing of the Dipper, the mechanisms of the *Yin Fu*, and the sacred texts of the Five Talismans and Five Victories. Thereupon, he vanquished Chiyou in the heartland of Jizhou.

After Shennong’s time, Yu Gang was executed at Banquan, and the realm was brought to great peace; the capital was established at Zhuolu in Shanggu. Some years later, the Queen Mother sent the White Tiger Spirit, who rode a white tiger to the Emperor’s court and presented him with a terrestrial map. In his later years, she again bestowed upon him the precepts of purity, non-action, and the rectification of the true, declaring: "Cease not from eating and drinking, and the body shall not be light; cease not from thought and worry, and the spirit shall not be clear; cease not from sound and color, and the heart shall not be at peace. If the heart is not at peace, the spirit shall not be efficacious; if the spirit is not efficacious, the Dao shall not be attained. Its essential subtlety lies not in gazing at stars or worshipping the Dipper, nor in afflicting the self or exhausting the body. Its nobility resides in the serenity of the square inch of the heart, free from all restless striving. Only thus may the Way of the immortals be mastered, and long life secured."

Later, when Yu Shun assumed the throne, the Queen Mother sent a messenger to present him with a white jade ring and bestowed upon Yi a terrestrial map, thereby expanding the Yellow Emperor’s Nine Provinces into twelve. The Queen Mother further dispatched a messenger to grant Shun the *huangguan* flute, by whose playing the eight winds were harmonized.

In the twenty-fifth year of King Zhao of Zhou, the cyclical year *yimao*, the Venerable Lord Lao and the Perfected One Yin Xi journeyed beyond the Eight Cords to wander in the west, arriving at Tortoise Terrace, where they expounded the *Changqingmo Jing* to the Queen Mother of the West. Thus, the Left Palace Immortal Duke Ge Xuan of the Great Ultimate later recorded: "I once received it from the Lord Emperor of the Eastern Flower; the Lord Emperor of the Eastern Flower received it from the Lord Emperor of the Golden Watchtower; the Lord Emperor of the Golden Watchtower received it from the Queen Mother of the West—all transmitted orally, without written record. Now, in this world, I commit it to writing."

In the time of King Mu, he commanded a chariot drawn by eight steeds: on the right rein, *Pili* and *Lü’er*; on the left, *Chiji* and *Baiyao*. The master charioteer was Zaofu, with Gaoju as his right-hand attendant. The second chariot bore on its right rein *Quhuang* and *Yulun*, and on its left, *Daoli* and *Yu*; its master was Boyao, with Canbai as charioteer and Benrong as right-hand attendant. They galloped a thousand *li* to reach the land of the Giant Sou clan.

chunks.original_text: 巨搜氏乃献白鹄之血以饮王，具牛马之潼以洗王之足。 及二乘之人已饮而行道，宿於昆仑之阿，赤水之阳。 别日升昆仑之丘，以观黄帝之宫，而封之以请后世。 遂宾於西王母，觞於瑶池之上。 西王母为王谣，王和之，其词一展焉。 乃观日之所入，一日行万里。 王乃叹曰：予一人不盈於德，后世其追数吾过乎。 又云：王持白珪重锦以为王母寿。 歌白云之谣，刻石纪边於彝山之上而还《纪年》云：穆王十七年西征，见西王母，宾于昭宫。 世之升天之仙，凡有九品，第一上仙，号九天真王。 第二次仙，号三天真皇。 第三号太上真人，第四号飞天真人，第五号灵仙，第六号真人，第七号灵人，第八号飞仙，第九号仙人。 凡此品次，不可差越。 然其升天之时，先拜木公，后谒金母。 受事既讫，方得升九天，入三清，拜太上，觐奉元始天尊耳。 故汉初有四五小儿戏於路，中一儿歌曰：着青裙，入天门，揖金母，拜木公。 时人莫知之，惟张子房知之，乃往拜焉，曰：此乃东王公之玉童也。 仙人得道升天，当揖金母而拜木公也。 自非冲虚登真之子，莫知其津矣。 汉武帝好长生之道，以元封元年登嵩高之岳，筑寻真之台，斋戒精思。 四月戊辰，王母使塘城玉女王子登来语帝曰：闻子欲轻四海之禄，迂万乘之贵，以求长生，真乎？ 勤哉。 七月七日，吾来暂来也。

The Giant Sou clan presented the blood of a white crane for the king to drink and prepared a broth of oxen and horses to wash his feet. When the two chariots' attendants had drunk and set forth on their journey, they lodged at the slopes of Kunlun, on the northern bank of the Red Water. The next day, they ascended the heights of Kunlun to behold the palace of the Yellow Emperor and sealed it with earth to petition for posterity. Then they were received as guests by the Queen Mother of the West, who feasted the king upon the Jasper Pool. The Queen Mother sang for the king, and the king harmonized with her, their verses unfolding as one. They observed the place where the sun sets, traveling ten thousand *li* in a single day.

The king sighed and said, "I, alone, am not full in virtue; will later generations recount my faults?" It is also said: the king held a white jade tablet and layered brocade to offer longevity to the Queen Mother. He sang the "Song of the White Clouds" and carved an inscription upon the border at Mount Yi before returning.

The *Bamboo Annals* states: "In the seventeenth year of his reign, King Mu journeyed west, met the Queen Mother of the West, and was received as a guest at the Radiant Palace."

Among those who ascend to heaven as immortals, there are nine ranks:
The first, the Supreme Immortal, is titled the True King of the Nine Heavens.
The second, the Lesser Immortal, is titled the True Sovereign of the Three Heavens.
The third is titled the Perfected of the Supreme, the fourth the Flying Perfected,
the fifth the Numinous Immortal, the sixth the Perfected,
the seventh the Numinous Being, the eighth the Flying Immortal,
and the ninth the Immortal.
These ranks must not be transgressed.

When ascending to heaven, one must first bow to the Lord of the East, then pay homage to the Queen Mother of the West. Only after completing these rites may one ascend to the Nine Heavens, enter the Three Clarities, bow before the Supreme, and behold the Celestial Worthy of Original Beginning.

Thus, in the early Han dynasty, four or five children played by the roadside. One among them sang:
*"Donning a blue skirt, entering the Gate of Heaven,
bowing to the Queen Mother of the West, saluting the Lord of the East."*
No one present understood, save Zhang Zifang, who went forth to bow and said, "These are the jade lads of the Lord of the East." For when immortals attain the Dao and ascend to heaven, they must salute the Queen Mother of the West and bow to the Lord of the East. None but those who have attained emptiness and ascended to perfection know this path.

Emperor Wu of Han was fond of the Dao of longevity. In the first year of the *Yuanfeng* era, he ascended Mount Songgao, built the Terrace of Seeking the Perfected, and fasted with utmost devotion. On the *wuchen* day of the fourth month, the Queen Mother dispatched Wang Zideng, a jade maiden of Tang City, to address the emperor: "I hear you wish to relinquish the emoluments of the Four Seas and forsake the dignity of the myriad chariots to seek longevity. Is this true? How diligent you are!" On the seventh day of the seventh month, she came briefly to visit.

chunks.original_text: 帝问东方朔审其神，应乃清斋百日，焚香宫中。 夜二唱后，白云起于西南，郁郁而至，径趋宫庭。 渐近则云霞九色，箫鼓震空。 龙凤人马之众，乘麟驾鹿之卫，科车天马，霓旅羽幢，千乘万骑，光耀宫阙。 大仙从官，森罗亿众，皆长丈余。 既至从官所在，王母乘紫云之辇，驾九色斑龙，带天真之策，佩金刚灵玺。 黄锦之服，文彩鲜明，金光奕奕。 腰分景色之剑，结飞云大绶。 头上华髻，戴太真晨缨之冠。 蹑方琼凤文之履。 可年二十许，天姿奄霭，灵颜绝世，真灵人也。 下车，二女扶侍，登床东向而坐。 帝拜跪问寒温，侍立良久，呼帝使坐。 设以天厨，芳华百果，紫芝萎蕊，纷若顼，精珍异常，非世所有，帝不能名也。 又命侍女取桃，玉盘盛七枚，大如鹌音保，与捣同子。 四以与帝，母自食三。 帝食桃，辄收其核。 母问何为，帝曰：欲种之尔。 母曰：此桃三千岁一实，中国土地薄种之不生。 於是命王子登弹八珍之傲，董双成吹云和之笙，石公子击昆廷之玉，许飞琼鼓震灵之簧，婉凌华村吾陵之石，范成君拍洞阴之磬，段安香作九天之钧，法婴歌玄灵之曲。 众声激清，朗音骇空。 歌毕，帝下席叩头，以问长生之道。 王母曰：汝能贱荣乐卑，耽虚味道，自复佳尔。 然汝性恣体欲，淫乱过甚，杀伐非法，奢侈恣性。 夫侈者裂身之具也，淫者破身之斧也，杀者响对，奢者心烂，积欲则神损，聚秽则命断。 以子蕞尔之身而宅残形之贼，盈尺之材而攻之者百刃，欲以解脱三尸，全身永久，不可得也。 有似无翅之钨愿鼓天池，朝生之菌而乐春秋者也。 若能荡此众乱，拨秽易意，保神气於绛府，闭瑶宫而不开，静奢侈以寂室，爱众生而不危，守慈务施，炼气惜精。 倘有若斯之事，岂无髻霏邪。 若不尔者，譬如抱石而济长河尔。 帝跪受王母之诚，曰：彻不才，沉沦流俗，承禅先业，遂羁世累，刑政乖缪，罪积丘山。 今日之后，请事斯语矣。 王母曰：夫养性之道，理身之要，汝固知矣，但在勤行不息也。 我师元始天王昔於严霄之台，授我要言，曰：欲长生者取诸身，坚守三一保灵根。 玄谷华体灌沈珍，既长清精入天门。 金室宛转在中关，青白分明适泥丸。 养液闭精具身神，三宫备卫存绛宫。 黄庭戊己无流源，彻通五藏十二轮。 吐纳六府魂魄欣，却此百病辟热寒，保精留命永长存。 此所谓呼太和，保守自然，真要道者也。 凡人为之，皆必长生，亦可役使鬼神，游戏五岳，但不得飞空腾虚而已。 汝能为之，足可度世也。 夫学仙者，未有不由此而始也。 至若太上灵药，上帝奇物也。 下阴生重云妙草，皆神仙之药也。 得上品者，后天而老，乃太上之所服，非下仙之所逮。 其次药有九丹，金液、紫华、虹英、太清、九转、五云之浆、玄霜绛雪、腾跃三黄、东瀛白香。 玄洲飞生、八石千芝、威喜九光、西流石胆、东沧青钱、高丘余粮、积石琼田、太虚还丹，盛以金兰、长光绛草、雪童飞干，有得服之，白日升天。 此飞仙之所服，非地仙之所闻。 其下药有松梧之膏、山姜、沈精、菊华、泽泻、枸杞、狭苓、莒蒲、门冬、巨胜、黄精、灵飞、赤板、桃胶、木英、升麻、续断、威袭、黄连，如此下药，略举其端。 草类繁多，名数有千，子得服之，可以延年，虽不能长享无期，上升青天，亦可以身生光泽，返老童颜，役使群鬼，得为地仙。

The emperor questioned Dongfang Shuo to verify the divinity’s authenticity. Shuo then purified himself with a hundred days of fasting and burned incense within the palace. After the second watch of the night, white clouds arose from the southwest, dense and billowing, advancing directly toward the palace courtyard. As they drew near, the clouds and mist took on nine hues, while flutes and drums shook the heavens. A throng of dragons, phoenixes, men, and horses—escorts riding unicorns and deer—accompanied chariots of jade, celestial steeds, banners of rainbow and feathers, and a procession of a thousand chariots and ten thousand riders, their radiance illuminating the palace towers. The great immortals and their retinue, arrayed in countless ranks, all stood over a *zhang* tall. Once they reached their appointed stations, the Queen Mother descended from her purple-cloud carriage, drawn by nine multicolored striped dragons, bearing the Heavenly Perfected Staff and the Golden Cinnabar Seal. Her robes of yellow brocade shimmered with vivid patterns, their golden light resplendent. At her waist hung the Sword of Radiant Splendor, tied with the Grand Sash of Flying Clouds. Upon her head rested an ornate topknot, crowned with the Dawn Diadem of the Supreme Perfected. Her slippers were embroidered with square jade and phoenix motifs. Though she appeared no older than twenty, her celestial grace was overwhelming, her divine countenance unmatched in the world—a true spirit among mortals.

Alighting from her carriage, two maidens supported her as she ascended the dais and sat facing east. The emperor knelt in obeisance, inquiring after her well-being, and stood in attendance for a long while before she bade him sit. She then presented him with the delicacies of the Heavenly Kitchen: fragrant blossoms, a hundred rare fruits, purple mushrooms and tender buds, their forms intricate and exquisite—treasures beyond the mortal realm, which the emperor could not name. She further commanded her attendants to bring peaches, seven of which were arranged upon a jade platter, each as large as a goose egg, their flesh like that of a jujube. Four she gave to the emperor, while she herself ate three. As the emperor consumed the peaches, he gathered their pits. When the Queen Mother asked why, he replied, “I wish to plant them.” She said, “This peach bears fruit but once every three thousand years. The soil of the Middle Kingdom is too meager for it to grow.”

Thereupon, she ordered Wang Zideng to pluck the strings of the Eight Rarities, Dong Shuangcheng to play the *yunhe* reed pipe, Shi Gongzi to strike the jade chimes of Kunlun, Xu Feiqiong to sound the divine reed organ, Wan Linghua to tap the stone chimes of Wuling, Fan Chengjun to beat the dark-toned chime, Duan Anxiang to perform the Nine Heavens’ melody, and Fa Ying to sing the *Xuanling* hymn. Their voices soared in crystalline purity, their clear notes startling the heavens. When the song concluded, the emperor descended from his seat, kowtowed, and inquired about the Dao of longevity.

The Queen Mother replied, “If you could scorn glory and delight in humility, immerse yourself in emptiness and savor the Dao, that would indeed be excellent. Yet your nature is indulgent, your desires unrestrained, your debauchery excessive, your killings unlawful, and your extravagance unbounded. Extravagance is the tool that rends the body, lust the axe that shatters it. Killing invites retribution, excess rots the heart. Accumulated desires deplete the spirit; gathered filth severs life. With your fragile frame as a den for thieves of decay, and your scant flesh assailed by a hundred blades, how can you hope to shed the Three Corpses, preserve your body, and endure forever? It would be like a wingless crane aspiring to soar over the celestial pools, or a morning mushroom hoping to enjoy the seasons. If you could sweep away these disorders, purge your impurities, and renew your resolve; safeguard your spirit and *qi* within the Crimson Palace, seal the Jade Chamber and never open it; still your extravagance in quietude, cherish all beings without harm; uphold compassion, practice generosity, refine your *qi*, and treasure your essence—then perhaps you might yet ascend in a halo of mist. If not, you are like one embracing a stone while fording a great river.”

The emperor knelt to receive the Queen Mother’s admonitions, saying, “I, Zhe, am unworthy, sunk in the mire of the vulgar world. Inheriting the legacy of my ancestors, I have been shackled by worldly burdens. My governance has been flawed, my crimes as vast as mountains. From this day forth, I shall heed your words.”

The Queen Mother replied, “The Dao of nurturing life and the essence of cultivating the body—you already know these principles. The key lies in diligent, unceasing practice. My master, the Primordial Heavenly King, once imparted to me on the Terrace of Stern Clarity these essential words: *‘To attain long life, draw from within yourself. Firmly guard the Three Ones and preserve the root of spirit. Bathe the Mystic Valley and the Flowery Body in the essence of deep tranquility. Once the pure essence has grown long, let it enter the Gate of Heaven. The Golden Chamber winds through the Central Pass; the Azure and White are distinct at the Mud Pill. Nurture the fluids, seal the essence, and unite body and spirit. The Three Palaces are fully defended, the Crimson Palace preserved. The Yellow Court and the earthly branches have no source of leakage; the five viscera and twelve wheels are thoroughly connected. Exhale and inhale the six bowels, and the hun and po rejoice. Repel the hundred ailments, ward off heat and cold. Preserve essence, retain life, and endure forever.’* This is what is called ‘summoning the Great Harmony, safeguarding the natural, and embracing the true essential Dao.’ If all people practice this, they will surely attain long life, command ghosts and spirits, and wander the Five Peaks—though they may not yet soar through the void. If you can achieve this, it will suffice to transcend the world. All who study immortality must begin here.

As for the supreme elixirs of the Most High, they are the wondrous treasures of the Celestial Emperor. The *xiayinsheng* and *chongyun* marvelous herbs are the medicines of the immortals. Those who obtain the highest grade will age only after Heaven and Earth, for these are consumed by the Most High—beyond the reach of lesser immortals. The next rank of medicines includes the Nine Elixirs: Golden Liquid, Purple Florescence, Rainbow Essence, Supreme Clarity, Ninefold Cyclic Transmutation, the Five Clouds’ Nectar, Mystic Frost and Crimson Snow, the Soaring Three Yellows, and Eastern Sea White Fragrance. There are also the Flying Life of the Dark Continent, the Eight Stones and Thousand Mushrooms, the Mighty Radiance of Nine Lights, the Western Flowing Stone Gall, the Eastern Azure Coin, the Remnant Grain of High Mounds, the Jade Fields of Accumulated Stones, the Celestial Return Elixir, the Golden Orchid vessel, the Everlasting Radiance herb, and the Flying Dryad of the Snow Lad. Those who consume these will ascend to heaven in broad daylight. These are the medicines of the flying immortals, unknown to earthbound immortals.

The lower-grade medicines include the fats of pine and *wutong*, *shanjiang*, *shenjing*, chrysanthemum blossoms, *zexie*, *gouqi*, *fuling*, *changpu*, *men* winter, *jusheng*, yellow essence, *lingfei*, red planks, peach resin, *muying*, *shengma*, *xuduan*, *weixi*, and *huanglian*. Such medicines, of which I have only begun to list, are countless in variety, numbering in the thousands. If you consume them, you may prolong your years. Though you may not achieve boundless longevity or ascend to the azure heavens, you can still restore the luster of youth, regain a childlike complexion, command legions of ghosts, and become an earthbound immortal.”

chunks.original_text: 求道之者，要先凭此阶，渐以入乎妙也。 若能呼吸御精，保固神气，精不脱则永久，气长存则不死，不用药石之费，又无营索之劳，取之於身尔，百姓日用不知，此故为上品自然之要也。 且夫一人之身，天付之以神，地付之以形，道付之以气。 气存则生，气去则死，万物草木，亦皆知之。 身以道为本，岂可不养神固气全尔形也。 形神俱全，上圣所贵。 形灭神逝，岂不痛哉。 一失此身，万劫难复，子其宝焉。 我之所言，乃我师元始天王所授之辞也。 即劝玉女李庆孙书出之，以付於帝曰：汝善修之焉。 王母命驾将去，帝下席叩头，请留。 王母即命侍女召上元夫人同降帝宫，良久，上元夫人至，复坐设天厨。 久之，王母命夫人出八会之书、五岳真形、五帝六甲灵飞之符，凡十二事，云：此书天上四万劫一传，若在人间，四十年可授有道之士。 王母乃命侍女宋灵宾开云锦之囊，取一册以授帝。 王母执书起，立以付帝。 王母呎曰：天尊地卑，五岳真形，元真激气，大泽玄精。 天回九道，六和长平，太上八会，飞天之成。 真仙节信，由兹通灵，泄坠灭府，宝归长龄。 彻其慎之，敢告刘生。 祝毕，帝拜受之。 王母曰：夫始学道受符者，宜别祭川岳诸真灵，洁斋而佩之焉。 四十年后，若将传付汝之所友，董仲君、李少君可校之尔。 况为帝王，可勤祭川岳以安国家，授简真灵以安黎庶也。 言讫，与上元夫人命车言去，从官互集，将欲登天。 因笑指束方朔：此我邻家小儿，性多滑稽，曾三来偷桃矣。 昔为太上仙官，因沈湎于玉酒，失部御之和，谪佐於汝，非流俗之夫也。 其后武帝不能用王母之戒，为酒色所惑，杀伐不休，征辽束，击朝鲜，通西南夷，筑台榭，兴土木，海内悉怨，自此失道。 幸回中，临束海，三祠王母，不复降焉。 所受之书，置于柏梁台上，为天火所焚。 李少君解形而去，束方朔飞翕不还，巫蛊事起，帝愈悔恨。 元始二年，崩於五祚宫，葬于茂陵。 其后茂陵所藏道书五十余卷，一日一出抱犊山中。 又玉箱玉杖出於扶风，市验茂陵，宛然如故。 而箱杖出於人问，径不知其果何为邪。 茅君盈字叔申，从西城王君诣白玉龟台，朝谒王母，求乞长生之道，曰：盈以不肖之躯，慕龙凤之年； 以朝菌之脆，求积朔之期。 王母愍其勤志，告之曰：吾昔师元始天王及皇天搏桑帝君，授我以玉佩金当、二景缠练之道，上行太极，下造十方，溉月咀日，以入天门，名日玄真之经。 今以授尔，宜勤修焉。 因劲西城王君一一解释以授之。

Those who seek the Dao must first rely on this stepping-stone to gradually enter into its mysteries. If one can master breath, govern essence, and secure the spirit and qi—so that essence does not dissipate and qi remains ever-present—one may achieve permanence without death. This requires no expenditure on medicines or stones, nor the toil of seeking and gathering, for it is drawn from within the self. Yet the common people use it daily without awareness—this is the highest, most natural essential method.

Now, the body of each person is endowed by Heaven with spirit, by Earth with form, and by the Dao with qi. Where qi abides, there is life; where qi departs, there is death—even plants and trees know this. Since the body takes the Dao as its root, how can one fail to nourish the spirit, secure the qi, and preserve the form? When form and spirit are both whole, the highest sages prize this above all. When form perishes and spirit flees, is it not grievous? Once this body is lost, it is difficult to recover even after ten thousand kalpas—cherish it well.

What I have spoken are the words taught to me by my master, the Primordial Heavenly King. I now urge the Jade Maiden Li Qingsun to transcribe them and present them to the Emperor, saying: "You must cultivate this diligently."

The Queen Mother of the West then ordered her carriage prepared to depart, but the Emperor rose from his seat, kowtowed, and begged her to stay. The Queen Mother commanded her attendants to summon the Supreme Primordial Lady to descend together to the Emperor’s palace. After a long while, the Supreme Primordial Lady arrived, and they sat once more to set out a celestial feast. Later, the Queen Mother instructed the Lady to bring forth the *Eight Assemblies Scripture*, the *True Forms of the Five Peaks*, the *Five Emperors and Six Jia Spirit-Flight Talismans*, and twelve items in all, saying: "This scripture is transmitted in Heaven only once every forty thousand kalpas. If it remains in the human realm, it may be passed to a worthy adept after forty years."

The Queen Mother then ordered her attendant Song Lingbin to open the cloud-brocade satchel and take out a volume to present to the Emperor. The Queen Mother held the book, stood, and handed it to him. She intoned:

"High is Heaven, low is Earth,
True forms of the Five Peaks,
Primordial true qi surges,
Great marsh’s mysterious essence.
Heaven revolves through nine paths,
Six harmonies endure in peace,
The Supreme Eight Assemblies,
Achieve flight to celestial realms.
True immortals keep faith,
Through this they commune with spirits.
Leaked, it falls to ruin’s depths—
Treasure it for long life’s sake.
Heed this well, I warn you, Liu."

After the incantation, the Emperor bowed and received the book. The Queen Mother said: "Those who first learn the Dao and receive talismans should separately offer sacrifices to the spirits of rivers and mountains, purify themselves in fasting, and wear them. After forty years, if you wish to transmit them to your friends, Dong Zhongjun and Li Shaojun may examine them. Moreover, as an emperor, you should diligently sacrifice to rivers and mountains to secure the state, and bestow these sacred texts upon the spirits to pacify the common people."

Having spoken, she and the Supreme Primordial Lady ordered their carriages to depart. Their attendants gathered, preparing to ascend to Heaven. The Queen Mother then smiled and pointed to Dongfang Shuo, saying: "This is my neighbor’s mischievous child, ever fond of jesting—he has come thrice to steal my peaches. Once a celestial official under the Supreme, he was demoted to serve you after indulging in jade wine and losing harmony in his administration. He is no ordinary man."

Later, Emperor Wu failed to heed the Queen Mother’s warnings, becoming ensnared by wine and women, ceaseless in warfare. He campaigned against Liaodong, struck at Chaoxian, opened routes to the southwestern barbarians, built terraces and pavilions, and launched grand construction projects. The realm grew resentful, and from then on, he lost the Dao. Though he later returned to Zhong, visited the Eastern Sea, and thrice sacrificed to the Queen Mother, she no longer descended. The book he had received was placed atop the Bailiang Terrace and consumed by heavenly fire. Li Shaojun departed by dissolving his form, while Dongfang Shuo flew away and did not return. The witchcraft affair arose, and the Emperor grew ever more remorseful. In the second year of the Yuanshi era, he died at the Five Blessings Palace and was buried at Maoling. Later, over fifty volumes of Daoist scriptures stored in Maoling emerged one day in the Baodu Mountains. A jade box and jade staff also appeared in Fufeng, and when taken to Maoling for verification, they remained unchanged. Yet how these objects came into the human world—and for what purpose—remains unknown.

Master Mao Ying, styled Shushen, followed the Lord of Western City to the White Jade Tortoise Terrace to pay homage to the Queen Mother and seek the Way of long life. He said: "Though my body is unworthy, I yearn for the years of dragons and phoenixes; though my life is as fragile as a morning mushroom, I seek the span of countless moons."

The Queen Mother, moved by his earnestness, told him: "I once studied under the Primordial Heavenly King and the Celestial Mulberry Emperor Lord, who taught me the Way of the Jade Girdle and Golden Pendants, the Two Radiant Bindings, ascending to the Great Ultimate, and descending to the Ten Directions. I bathed in moonlight and sipped sunlight to enter the Celestial Gate—this is called the *Scripture of Mysterious Truth*. I now transmit it to you; cultivate it diligently." She then urged the Lord of Western City to explain each detail and bestow it upon him.

And she bestowed upon him the *Precious Writings of the Four Divine Lads* and the *Dispersed Methods*. Later, Lord Mao retreated south to govern Mount Juqu.

In the second year of Emperor Yuan’s *Yuanshou* era, on the *jiyou* day of the eighth month, the Perfected of the Southern Marchmount, the Red Lord; the Lord of Western City; and the Azure Lad of Fangzhu all descended from the Queen Mother to Lord Mao’s chamber. Shortly after, the Celestial August Emperor dispatched the Embroidered-Robe Messenger, Ling Guangziqi, to confer upon Mao the divine seal and jade tally. The Lord of the Grand Tenuity sent the Left Palace Censor of the Three Heavens, Guan Xiutiao, to bestow upon him the *Eight-Dragon Brocade Palanquin* and the *Purple Feathered Robe of Splendor*. The Supreme Lord of the Great Dao sent the Harmonious Dawn Gentleman, Shi Shumen, to present him with the *True Talisman of the Golden Tiger*, the *Flowing Gold Bells*, and the *Golden Watchtower Saintly Lord* commanded the Perfected of the Great Ultimate to dispatch the Jade Gentleman of the Supreme Unity and Upper Mystery, Wang Zhong and Bao Qiu, to grant Mao the *Four-Season Swallow Embryo*, the *Flowing Brightness Divine Mushroom*.

When the four messengers had finished their transmissions, they had Mao don the seal, robe, and talisman, adjust his cap and sash, and stand holding the bells. The four messengers then addressed Mao, saying:

"One who consumes the *Hidden Mushroom of the Four Seasons* shall be ranked as a Perfected Minister.
One who consumes the *Jade Mushroom of the Golden Watchtower* shall be ranked as Controller of Destinies.
One who consumes the *Flowing Brightness Golden Essence* shall be ranked as Controller of Emoluments.
One who consumes the *Double-Flying of Eternal Radiance* shall be ranked as Perfected Earl.
One who consumes the *Night-Glowing Cave Herb* shall preside over the duties of the Left and Right Censors.
You have consumed them all. Your lifespan shall equal that of Heaven and Earth, and your rank shall be Controller of Destinies. You are appointed as the Upper Minister of the Eastern Marchmount, governing the immortals of Wu and Yue, and overseeing the mountain sources of Jiangzuo."

When they had finished speaking, the messengers all departed. The Lords of the Five Directions each descended to his courtyard in their directional chariots and regalia, transmitting the Celestial August Emperor’s command to bestow upon Mao the *Purple Jade Tablet*, the *Yellow Gold Inscribed Writ*, and the *Text of the Nine Bestowments*. He was then enfeoffed as the *Perfected Lord Controller of Destinies and Upper Minister of the Eastern Marchmount*, and the *Perfected of the Great Primordium*. When the investiture was complete, they all departed.

The Queen Mother and Mao’s master, the Lord of Western City, then prepared a celestial banquet for Mao. They feasted to their hearts’ content and sang the *Song of the Mysterious Numinous*. When the banquet concluded, the Queen Mother, accompanied by the Lord of Western City and Mao, visited Mao’s two younger brothers and imparted to each the essentials of the Dao.

The Queen Mother commanded the Lady of the Upper Prime to bestow upon Mao Gu and Mao Zhong the *Hidden Writ of the Grand Empyrean*, the *Scripture of Cinnabar Radiance*, and four other treasured scriptures. Holding the *Hidden Writ of the Grand Empyrean*, the Queen Mother ordered the handmaiden Zhang Lingzi to hold the *Pact of Mutual Trust* and present it to Mao, Gu, and Zhong. When the transmission was complete, the Queen Mother ascended to Heaven and departed.

Later, Wang Bao, styled Zideng; Zhang Daoling, styled Fuhan; and the Nine Sages and Seven Perfected—all who had received the scriptures—paid homage to the Queen Mother at the Gate of Kunling.

Thereafter, the Lady of Purple Emptiness, Madame Wei Huacun, purified herself in retreat at the *Hidden Primordium Terrace* of Yangluo. The Queen Mother, together with the Saintly Lord of the Golden Watchtower, descended to the terrace in an *Eight-Scenery Cloud Chariot* and proceeded to the *Palace of Pure Emptiness*, where she transmitted the four-scroll *Hidden Writ of the Jade Clarity* to Huacun. At that time, over thirty Perfected Ones—including the Lady of the Three Primes, Feng Shuangli; the Left Immortal Duke of Purple Yang, Shi Lucheng; the High Immortal Earl of the Great Ultimate, Yan Gaigongzi; the Perfected of Western City, Wang Fangping; the Perfected of Grand Emptiness, the Red Pine of the Southern Marchmount; and the Perfected of Tongbai, Wang Ziqiao—each sang the *Yin and Yang Songs of the Great Ultimate*. The Queen Mother then sang:

"I ride my *Eight-Scenery Chariot*,
Serene, I enter the *Jade Clarity*.
Dragon banners brush the clouds above,
Tiger legions command the crimson hosts.
Carefree at the edge of the Mystic Ford,
Ten thousand streams never pause for a moment.
Once this parting and reunion is done,
When kalpas end and Heaven and Earth collapse,
Seek the scene within the Non-Being,
Neither death nor life shall bind you.
Embody the Dao of spontaneity,
In silent contemplation merge with the Great Obscurity.
The Southern Marchmount nurtures the true trunk,
Jade’s radiance gleams with luminous essence.
In office, be free of its burdens,
With an empty heart, naturally receive the numinous.
A joyous gathering at the bend of the Crimson River,
Together we delight without end."

When she finished singing, the Lady of the Upper Prime responded with her own song. Then the Queen Mother, the Lady of the Upper Prime, the Left Immortal Duke of Purple Yang, the Immortal Earl of the Great Ultimate, and the Perfected Lord of Pure Emptiness took the Southern Marchmount’s Wei Huacun with them as they traveled southeast to the Jade Palace beneath the Cavernous Palace of Mount Huo on Tiantai. All the Perfected followed the Queen Mother as she ascended and returned to Tortoise Terrace.

The Queen Mother is the preceptor of the myriad kinds, the overseer of the host of Perfected. Her sacred rank is most exalted, and she governs both the hidden and the manifest. Thus, when the Dark Cavern’s Xuan Gong sought the Dao, he received it in audience, and when Xie Ziranjing attended her to ascend as an immortal, the *Transmission of the Dark Cavern* and the *Transmission of Ziran* both call the Golden Mother their teacher. The attested matters in the mysterious scriptures are many, but most cannot be recorded in full.

*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embodied the Dao Through the Ages, First Scroll* concludes.

chunks.original_text: 九天玄女 九天玄女者，黄帝之师、圣母元君弟子也。 黄帝在昔为有熊之国君，佐神农之孙榆冈。 既衰，诸侯相伐，干戈相寻，各据方色，自称五行之号，太嗥之后，自为青帝。 榆冈神农之后，自号赤帝。 共工之族自号白帝，葛天氏之后自号黑帝。 帝起有熊之墟，自号黄帝。 帝乃恭己下士，侧身修德。 在位二十一年，而蚩尤肆孽，弟兄八十一人，兽身人语，铜头铁额，瞰砂吞石，不殖五谷。 作五虐之刑以害黎庶，铸兵於葛炉之山，不用帝命。 帝欲征之，博求贤能，以为己助。 得风台於海隅，得力牧於大泽，以大鸿为佐，天老为师。 置三公以象三台，风后为上台，天老为中台，五圣为下台。 始获宝鼎，不爨而熟。 迎日推策以封胡为将，以夫人费修之子为太子，用张若阳朋、力牧、容光、龙行、苍颉、容成、大挠、奢龙众臣以为羽翼，战蚩尤於涿鹿。 帝师不胜。 蚩尤作大雾三日，内外皆迷。 风后法斗机，作大车，以杓指南，以正四方。 帝用忧愤斋於太山之下，王母遣使披玄狐之裘，以符授帝曰：精思告天，必有太上之应。 居数日，大雾冥冥昼晦，玄女降焉。 乘丹凤，御景云，服九色彩翠之衣，集于帝前，帝再拜受命，玄女曰：吾行太上之教，有疑可问也。 帝稽首曰：蚩尤暴横，毒害需黎，四海嗷嗷，莫保性命。 欲一战必胜之术，与人除害，可乎？ 玄女即授帝六甲六壬兵信之符，灵宝五符策使鬼神之书，制祆通灵五明之印，五阴五阳遁甲之式，太一十精四神胜负握机之图，五岳河图策精之诀，九光玉节十绝灵婶命魔之剑，霞冠火佩龙戟霓旅翠辈绿耕此縿虎骑千花之盖，八鸾之舆羽钥玄竿虹旌玉越神仙之物，五龙之印九明之珠九天之节，以为兵信五色之磨，以辨五方。 帝遂复率诸侯再战。 蚩尤驱魑魅杂祆以为阵，雨师风伯以为卫，应龙蓄水以攻帝。

Nine Heavens Mystic Maiden

The Nine Heavens Mystic Maiden was the teacher of the Yellow Emperor and a disciple of the Primordial Sovereign Saintly Mother. In ancient times, the Yellow Emperor ruled the state of Youxiong, assisting Yugang, grandson of Shennong. As the latter’s power waned, the feudal lords turned to warfare, their weapons clashing endlessly. Each claimed dominion over a cardinal direction and styled themselves after the Five Phases: the descendants of Taihao proclaimed themselves the Bluegreen Emperor; the lineage of Yugang, grandson of Shennong, called themselves the Red Emperor; the clan of Gonggong named themselves the White Emperor; the heirs of Getian declared themselves the Black Emperor. The Emperor, rising from the lands of Youxiong, took the title of Yellow Emperor.

He governed with humility, honoring the worthy and cultivating virtue. After twenty-one years on the throne, Chiyou wrought havoc—his eighty-one brothers, beast-bodied and human-tongued, with copper heads and iron brows, devoured sand and swallowed stones, refusing to till the five grains. They devised the Five Cruelties to torment the common folk, forged weapons on Mount Gelu, and defied the Emperor’s commands. Resolved to subdue them, the Emperor sought the wise and capable to aid him. He found Fengtai by the sea, Limu in the great marsh, appointed Dahong as his assistant, and Tianlao as his teacher. He established the Three Dukes to mirror the Three Terraces: Fenghou as the Upper Terrace, Tianlao as the Middle Terrace, and the Five Sages as the Lower Terrace. He then obtained a sacred tripod that cooked without fire. Following the solar cycles, he enfeoffed Hu as general and named Lady Feixiu’s son as crown prince. With ministers such as Zhang Ruoyangpeng, Limu, Rongguang, Longxing, Cangjie, Rongcheng, Danao, and Shelong as his wings, he marched against Chiyou at Zhuolu. Yet the Emperor’s forces could not prevail.

Chiyou conjured a three-day fog, shrouding all in disorientation. Fenghou, emulating the Dipper’s mechanism, crafted a great chariot with a ladle pointing south to orient the four directions. The Emperor, grieving and indignant, fasted at the foot of Mount Tai. The Queen Mother dispatched an envoy clad in a black fox-fur robe, presenting him with a talisman and instructing: “Concentrate your spirit and petition Heaven—there shall be a response from the Supreme.” Days later, amid a vast, lightless fog, the Mystic Maiden descended. Riding a cinnabar phoenix and wreathed in radiant clouds, she wore a nine-hued robe of kingfisher plumes. Alighting before the Emperor, he bowed twice and received her command. She declared: “I transmit the teachings of the Supreme. Ask what you will.”

The Emperor prostrated himself and said: “Chiyou’s tyranny poisons the people; the Four Seas cry out, their lives unprotected. I seek a strategy to ensure victory in a single battle, to rid the world of this scourge. Is this possible?”

The Mystic Maiden then bestowed upon him the Six Jia and Six Ren military talismans, the *Book of the Five Numinous Talismans for Commanding Ghosts and Spirits*, the *Five Luminous Seals for Subduing Demons and Communing with Spirits*, the *Formulae of the Five Yin and Five Yang Escape Arts*, the *Diagram of the Supreme Unity’s Ten Essences and Four Spirits for Grasping Victory*, the *Oracle of the Five Peaks and River Chart’s Essence*, the *Nine Radiant Jade Tallies and Ten Absolute Spirit Cords*, the *Sword for Commanding Demons*, the *Mist Crown and Flame Girdle*, the *Dragon Halberd and Rainbow Banner*, the *Kingfisher Canopy and Green Plow*, the *Tiger Cavalry and Thousand-Flower Canopy*, the *Eight-Phoenix Chariot*, the *Feathered Key and Mystic Pole*, the *Rainbow Standard and Jade Chime*, and other divine artifacts: the *Five Dragons’ Seal*, the *Nine Luminous Pearls*, and the *Nine Heavens’ Tallies*. These served as military tokens and five-colored whetstones to distinguish the five directions.

The Emperor then led the feudal lords into battle once more. Chiyou marshaled specters and demons into his ranks, with the Rain Master and Wind Earl as his guards. The Responding Dragon hoarded water to assail the Emperor.

chunks.original_text: 帝尽制之，遂灭蚩尤於绝辔之野、中冀之乡。 冢分其四肢以葬之。 由是榆冈拒命，又诛之於版泉之野。 北逐埙斋，大定四方，步四极凡二万八千里，乃铸鼎立九州，置九行、九德之臣，以观天地，祠百灵，垂法设教。 然后采首山之铜，铸鼎於刑山之下。 黄龙下迎，帝乘龙升天。 皆玄女之所授符策图局，以佐成功业。 蠢女 蜀之先有蚕丛帝。 又高辛时，蜀有蚕女，不知姓氏。 父为人所掠，惟所乘马在。 女念父，不食，其母因誓於众曰：有得父还者，以此女嫁之。 马闻其言，惊跃振迅，绝其拘绊而去。 数日父乃乘马而归。 自此马嘶呜，不肯龄。 母以誓众之言告父，父曰：誓於人，不誓於马，安有人而偶非类乎。 能脱我於难，功亦大矣，所誓之言不可行也。 马跑，父怒欲杀之。 马愈跑，父射杀之，曝其皮於庭。 皮蹶然而起，卷女飞去。 旬日皮复栖于桑上，女化为蚕，食桑叶吐丝成茧，以衣被於人问。 一日，蚕女乘云驾此马，侍卫数千人，谓父母曰：太上以我心不忘义，授以九宫仙嫔矣，毋复忆念也。 今冢在汉州什郁德阳三县界，每岁祈蚕者四方云集。 蜀之风俗，宫观诸化塑女像，披马皮，谓之马头娘，以祈蚕焉《周礼·夏官》马质掌质马云：若有马讼，则听之，禁原蚕者。 郑玄注云：原，再也。 天文辰为马蚕书，蚕为龙精，月直大火，则浴其种。 是蚕与马同气，物不能两大。 禁再蚕者，为伤马与。 据此之论，蚕马气类，世必有深究其理者。 道一特书之以俟。 云华夫人

The Emperor subdued them all, vanquishing Chiyou upon the wilds of Absolute Rein and the lands of Central Ji. His limbs were severed and buried in four separate mounds. Thereafter, Yu Gang defied the Mandate, and the Emperor slew him upon the plains of Banquan. He drove the Xunzhai northward, pacifying the Four Directions, traversing the Four Poles—a journey of twenty-eight thousand li—before casting the Nine Tripods and establishing the Nine Provinces. He appointed ministers of the Nine Ranks and Nine Virtues to observe the heavens and earth, to sacrifice to the hundred spirits, and to promulgate laws and teachings. Then, gathering copper from Mount Shou, he cast the tripods beneath Mount Xing. A yellow dragon descended to receive him, and the Emperor ascended to heaven upon its back. All this was achieved through the talismans, strategies, and diagrams bestowed by the Mysterious Woman to aid his great enterprise.

In ancient times, the Shu region had the Silkworm Ancestor, Can Cong. During the reign of Gao Xin, there lived in Shu a Silkworm Maiden, whose surname is unknown. Her father was carried off by raiders, leaving only his horse behind. Grieving for her father, the maiden refused to eat, and her mother swore before all: "Whoever brings my husband home shall have this daughter in marriage." Hearing these words, the horse reared in astonishment, broke free of its bonds, and galloped away. Days later, the father returned, riding the very same horse. From that day, the horse neighed incessantly and would not be stilled. The mother recounted her vow to the father, who replied: "A vow made to men cannot bind a beast. How could a human wed one of another kind? Though it saved me from peril, its deed was great, the oath cannot be fulfilled." The horse continued to prance wildly, and in anger, the father slew it, flaying its hide and drying it in the courtyard. Suddenly, the hide leapt up, wrapped the maiden within it, and flew away. Ten days later, the hide came to rest upon a mulberry tree, and the maiden transformed into a silkworm, feeding on the leaves and spinning cocoons to clothe mankind. One day, the Silkworm Maiden descended upon clouds, riding that very horse, attended by thousands of guards. She spoke to her parents: "The Supreme One, seeing my heart unwavering in righteousness, has granted me the rank of Celestial Consort of the Nine Palaces. Do not grieve for me." Her tomb now lies at the border of three counties—Shiyu, Deyang, and Han Prefecture—where each year, those who pray for silkworms gather from all directions. In Shu’s customs, temples and shrines sculpt her image draped in horsehide, calling her the Horse-Head Maiden, to invoke blessings for sericulture.

The *Rites of Zhou*, in the *Offices of Summer*, states that the Horse Assessor oversees horse transactions and adjudicates disputes, forbidding the raising of "original silkworms." Zheng Xuan’s commentary explains: "Original means second. The celestial sign of Chen governs horses; the *Silkworm Book* says silkworms are the essence of dragons. When the moon aligns with the Great Fire, their eggs are bathed. Thus, silkworms and horses share the same qi, and things cannot both be great. The prohibition on second silkworms is to avoid harming horses." From this discourse, the affinity between silkworms and horses is evident, and there must be those in the world who delve deeply into its principles. The Dao records this singular account in anticipation.

chunks.original_text: 夏禹治水，随山浚川，老君遣云华夫人往阴相之。 时禹驻巫山之下，大风卒至，崖谷振陨，力不可制。 忽遇云华夫人，禹拜而求助。 夫人即劫侍女授禹策召鬼神之书，因命其神狂章、虞余、黄麾、大翳、庚辰、童律、巨灵神等，助其斩石疏波，次塞导呃。 禹尝谒云华於崇嗽之巅。 顾盼之际，化而为石。 或倏然飞腾，散为轻云，油然而止，聚为夕雨。 或为游龙，或为翔鹤，千态万状，不可亲也。 禹疑其狡脍怪诞，非真仙也。 问诸童律，童律曰：天地之本者道也，运道之用者圣也。 圣之品次，真人、仙人也。 其有禀气成真，不修而得道者，木公、金母是也。 盖二气之祖，宗阴阳之原，本仙真之主宰，造化之元先。 云华夫人者，金母之女也总仙奇记云：名瑶姬。 受书为云华上宫夫人，主领教童真之士。 理在玉映之台，隐见变化，盖其常也。 亦由凝气成真，与道合体，非寓胎禀化之形，乃西华少阴之气也。 且气能弥纶天地，经营动植，大包造化，细入毫发。 在人为人，在物为物，岂止为云雨龙鹤、飞鸿腾凤哉。 禹然之，复往诣焉。 忽见云楼玉台，琼阙森然，灵官侍卫，不可名识。 师子抱关，天马启途，毒龙电兽，八威备轩。 夫人宴坐於琼台之上，禹稽首问道，召禹坐而谓曰：夫圣匠肇兴，剖大混之一朴，判为亿万之体。 发大蕴之一苞，散为无穷之物。 故步三光而立乎晷景，封九域而制乎邦国。 刻漏以分昼夜，寒暑以定岁纪，坎离以正方面，山川以分阴阳，城郭以聚民，器械以卫众，舆服以表贵贱，禾黍以备凶歉，凡此之制，上禀乎星辰而取法乎神真，下以养於有形之物。 是故日月有幽明，生杀有寒暑。 雷电有出入之期，风雨有动静之常。 类气浮乎上，而众精散於下。 废兴之数，治乱之运，贤愚之质，善恶之性，刚柔之气，寿夭之命，贵贱之位，尊卑之序，吉凶之感，穷达之期，此皆禀之於道，悬之於天，而圣人为纪也。 性发乎天而命成乎人，立之者天行之者道。 道存则有，道去则无。 非道则物不可存也。 非修则道不可致也。 太上有言：致虚极，守静笃，万物将自复。 复谓归於道，常存也。 道之用也，变化万端而不足其一。 是故天参玄玄，地参混黄，人参道德。 去此之外，非道也哉。 长久之要者，天保其玄，地守其物，人养其气，所以全也。 则我命在我，非天地杀之，鬼神害之，失道而自逝也。 志乎哉，勤乎哉，子之功及於物矣，勤逮於我矣，善格夫天矣，而未闻至道也。 吾昔於紫清之阙受书，宝而勤之，我师三元道君曰：上真内经，天真所宝。 封之金台，佩之太微，则云输上往，神虎抱关。 振衣瑶房，遨宴希林，长招仙公，右栖白山而下盼太空。 泛乎天津则乘云骋龙，游此名山则真人诣房。 万神奉卫，千精伺迎。 动有八景玉轮，静则宴处金堂。 亦谓之太上玉佩金当之妙文也。 汝将欲越巨海而无讽输，渡飞沙而无云轩，陆呃涂而无所舆，涉泥波而无所乘。 陆则困於远绝，水则惧於漂沦。 将欲以导百谷而浚万川也，危乎悠哉。 太上愍汝之至，将授汝以灵宝真文，陆策虎豹，水制蛟龙，斩诚万邪，检取群凶，以成汝之功也，其在乎阳明之天矣。 吾所授宝书，亦可以出入水火，啸叱幽冥，收策虎豹，呼召六丁，隐沦八地，颠倒五星，久视存身，与天地相倾也。
chunks.translated_text:
When Yu of Xia governed the waters, dredging rivers along the mountains, the Venerable Lord dispatched Cloud Radiance Lady to assist him in secret. At the time, Yu had stationed himself beneath Mount Wu, when a great wind suddenly arose, shaking cliffs and valleys, its force uncontrollable. Suddenly, he encountered Cloud Radiance Lady, and Yu bowed, seeking her aid. The Lady then compelled her attendants to bestow upon Yu the *Book of Summoning Ghosts and Spirits*, and commanded her divine ministers—Kuang Zhang, Yu Yu, Huang Hui, Da Yi, Geng Chen, Tong Lü, and the Giant Spirit—to assist him in hewing stone, dredging waves, blocking torrents, and guiding currents.

Yu once paid homage to Cloud Radiance atop the summit of Chong Sou. In the blink of an eye, she transformed into stone. At times, she would suddenly soar aloft, scattering into wispy clouds, then gently coalescing into evening rain. Now a roving dragon, now a soaring crane, her thousand forms and myriad shapes defied approach. Yu suspected her of cunning trickery, deeming her no true immortal. He inquired of Tong Lü, who replied: "The root of Heaven and Earth is the Dao; the function of the Dao is wielded by the sage. Among the ranks of sages are Perfected Ones and Immortals. Some, endowed with primordial qi, attain the Dao without cultivation—such are Wood Lord and Metal Mother, the progenitors of the Two Qi, the origin of yin and yang, the sovereigns of the immortals, and the primal source of creation. Cloud Radiance Lady is the daughter of Metal Mother. *The Marvelous Records of the Immortals* states her name is Yao Ji. She received scriptures and became Lady of the Upper Palace of Cloud Radiance, presiding over the instruction of youthful Perfected Ones. Her abode is the Terrace of Jade Reflection, where her transformations in concealment and manifestation are her constant nature. For she coalesced from congealed qi, uniting with the Dao in form—not born of womb or endowed with mortal transformation, but the qi of the Lesser Yin of Western Radiance. Moreover, qi pervades Heaven and Earth, animating the animate and inanimate, encompassing creation in its vastness, penetrating even the finest hair. In man, it is man; in things, it is things. How could it be confined to clouds and rain, dragons and cranes, soaring geese or ascending phoenixes?"

Yu was convinced and sought her again. Suddenly, he beheld a terrace of cloud and jade, its jasper towers resplendent, with spirit-officials standing guard, their forms beyond naming. Lions held the gates, celestial steeds cleared the path, venomous dragons and lightning beasts arrayed in eightfold majesty before her chariot. The Lady sat in repose upon the jasper terrace. Yu prostrated himself and inquired of the Dao. She summoned him to sit and said: "When the sagely artisan first arose, he split the great undifferentiated simplicity into countless forms, unfurled the vast storehouse’s single bud into boundless things. Thus, he paced the Three Luminaries to establish the sundial’s shadow, demarcated the Nine Regions to govern states and kingdoms, carved clepsydrae to divide day and night, used cold and heat to fix the year’s reckoning, aligned kan and li to rectify the cardinal directions, separated mountains and rivers into yin and yang, gathered the people within city walls, forged weapons to defend the multitude, fashioned carriages and robes to distinguish noble and base, and cultivated millet to prepare for famine. All these institutions draw their pattern from above from the stars and constellations, and from below take their model from the divine Perfected. Thus, the sun and moon have their obscurity and brightness, life and death follow cold and heat, thunder and lightning have their times of emergence and retreat, wind and rain their rhythms of movement and stillness. Kindred qi floats above, while manifold essences scatter below. The cycles of rise and fall, the turns of order and chaos, the natures of worthy and foolish, the dispositions of good and evil, the qi of firmness and softness, the fates of long and short life, the stations of noble and base, the ranks of high and low, the omens of fortune and misfortune, the junctures of success and failure—all these are endowed by the Dao, suspended from Heaven, and made manifest by the sage.

"Nature arises from Heaven, but destiny is fulfilled by man. Heaven establishes it; the Dao enacts it. Where the Dao abides, there is being; where it departs, there is nothing. Without the Dao, things cannot endure. Without cultivation, the Dao cannot be attained. The Most High has said: 'Attain utmost emptiness, preserve profound stillness, and the myriad things will revert of themselves.' To revert is to return to the Dao, to abide perpetually. The function of the Dao is inexhaustible in its ten thousand transformations. Thus, Heaven partakes of the Threefold Mystery, Earth of the Primal Yellow, and man of virtue and power. Beyond these, there is no Dao.

"The essentials of longevity are these: Heaven preserves its mystery, Earth guards its things, and man nurtures his qi—thus is wholeness maintained. Then my life is in my own hands; neither Heaven and Earth slay me, nor ghosts and spirits harm me, but I lose the Dao and perish of myself. Be steadfast! Be diligent! Your merit extends to all things, your toil reaches even me, your virtue moves Heaven—yet you have not heard the Supreme Dao.

"Long ago, at the Purple Clarity Gate, I received scriptures and treasured them with diligence. My master, the Three Primordials Lord of the Dao, said: 'The *Inner Scripture of the Supreme Perfected* is the treasure of the Heavenly Perfected. Seal it in a golden terrace, wear it at the Great Tenuity, and clouds will convey you upward while divine tigers guard the gates. Shake out your robes in the jasper chamber, roam and feast in the rare groves, ever summoning the Immortal Lords. On the right, dwell upon White Mountain and gaze down upon the Great Void. Drift upon the Celestial Ford, riding clouds and driving dragons; wander these famous mountains, and the Perfected will visit your chamber. Ten thousand spirits attend you, a thousand essences welcome you. In motion, you ride the Eight Radiance Jade Chariot; in stillness, you repose in the Golden Hall.' This is also called the wondrous scripture of the *Jade Girdle and Golden Pendant of the Most High*.

"You seek to cross vast seas without a swift vessel, traverse flying sands without a cloud-borne chariot, tread treacherous paths without a carriage, ford muddy waves without a boat. On land, you will be wearied by distant barriers; on water, you will fear drifting and sinking. Yet you would guide the hundred valleys and dredge the myriad rivers—how perilous and distant is your task! The Most High pities your utmost devotion and will bestow upon you the *Numinous Treasure True Writ*, to command tigers and leopards on land, subdue dragons in water, sever the roots of myriad evils, restrain the multitude of malevolence, and accomplish your work. This lies within the Heaven of Yang Brightness.

"The precious scripture I bestow can also enable you to enter and exit fire and water, roar and summon the netherworld, command tigers and leopards, call forth the Six Dings, conceal yourself in the Eight Earths, invert the Five Stars, prolong vision and preserve the body, and align with Heaven and Earth in duration."

chunks.original_text: 因命侍女陵容华出丹玉之岌，开上清宝文，以授禹。 仍命狂章、巨灵等神，助禹诛为民害，人力所不能制者。 戮防风氏於会稽，锁淮涡之神无支祇於龟山，皆其力也。 禹后入阳明洞天，为紫庭真人。 姮娥 羿请不死之药於西王母，妻姐娥窃而服之，奔月宫。 织女 织女上应天宿，牵牛则河鼓是也。 旧说天河与海通，汉时有人居海上者，年年八月见有浮搓去来，不失期。 人有奇志者，立飞阁其上，多资粮乘搓而去。 十余日至一处，有城郭状，屋舍甚严。 遥望室中，有织妇人。 又见一丈夫牵牛饮之，惊问曰：何由至此？ 其人与说来意，因问：此是何处？ 答曰：君至蜀郡访严君平，则知之。 因还，后以问君平。 君平曰：某年月日有客星犯牵牛宿，计年月正是此人到天河时也。 束方朔神异记云：郭翰尝遇织女降其室，衣玄霄之衣，霜罗之被，戴翘凤金冠，蹑琼文九章之履，张霜雾丹谷之祷，施九晶玉华之蕈，转会风之扇，有同心龙枕。 翌日，丹铅书青缣一幅以寄翰。 《汉书》：董永少失母养，父家贫，佣力至农。

Then she commanded the attendant maiden Ling Ronghua to bring forth the cinnabar-jade casket, open the *Precious Writ of Supreme Purity*, and bestow it upon Yu. She further ordered the gods Kuang Zhang and Ju Ling, among others, to assist Yu in slaying those who harmed the people—beings beyond mortal strength to subdue. The execution of Fangfeng at Kuaiji and the shackling of Wuzhiqi, the spirit of the Huai and Wo rivers, beneath Tortoise Mountain were among their feats. Later, Yu entered the Grotto-Heaven of Yang Brightness and became the Perfected One of the Purple Court.

Chang’e begged the Elixir of Immortality from the Queen Mother of the West; her wife, Heng’e, stole and consumed it, fleeing to the Lunar Palace. The Weaving Maiden corresponds to the celestial asterism above, while the Herdboy is the River Drum. An old account tells that the Celestial River connects with the sea: in the Han era, a man dwelling by the sea would see rafts floating to and fro each eighth month, never failing their appointed time. A man of extraordinary ambition built a flying pavilion atop one, stocked ample provisions, and rode the raft away. After more than ten days, he reached a place with walled cities and well-ordered houses. Gazing afar into a chamber, he saw a woman weaving. Another man appeared, leading an ox to drink. Startled, they asked, “How have you come here?” The traveler explained his purpose, then inquired, “What is this place?” They replied, “Go to Shu Commandery and seek Yan Junping—he will know.” Upon his return, he asked Junping, who said, “On such-and-such a day of such-and-such a year, a guest star trespassed upon the Herdboy asterism. By my reckoning, that was precisely when you reached the Celestial River.”

The *Divine Marvels of Dongfang Shuo* records: Guo Han once encountered the Weaving Maiden descending into his chamber. She wore a gown of dark auroral silk and a cloak of frost-spun gauze, a golden crown with phoenix plumes, and slippers embroidered with ninefold jade patterns. She unfurled a canopy of cinnabar mist and cinnabar valley, spread a mat of ninefold crystalline jade, turned a fan of converging winds, and rested upon a pillow of entwined dragons. The next day, she inscribed a strip of azure silk with cinnabar and lead, leaving it for Han.
